plan: Plan to test multiple bidding strategies, including aggressive high bids to gain data on competitors' tendencies, low-range bids to learn behavior when 'outscored', and mid-range bids for balanced insight. Also, I will track bidding patterns and adapt: if competitors bid high, I will explore lower-end; if they bid lower, I'll test high bids. Furthermore, I will experiment with randomized bidding to create uncertainty, and sequential lowering or raising bids by small increments strategy.

Initially, I plan to make medium to high bids, in the range of $50 to $99 to gather data on my opponents' strategies. Then, based on the bidding behavior of Andy and Charles, I'll adapt my strategy. If they are consistently bidding low, I'll reduce my bids to slightly above their average for potential profits. If they bid high, I'll selectively bid high when my value is high and bid low otherwise. Periodically, I'll make aggressive high bids for observational purposes. This mix of strategic and aggressive bidding will optimize user profit in the long run.

I plan to experiment with a range of bids from high, medium, to low values to gauge competition and assess possible profit margins. I will first start with aggressive high bids for data collection. If unsuccessful or margins are thin, I will transition to conservative low bids, then to moderate bids based on the data and competition pattern. Through progressive learning and adjusting bid strategy, I aim to maximize profit in the long run without risking too much capital in the early stage.

Plan to start with a mid-range bid of $50. Gradually reduce it in further rounds to gauge opponents' tendencies. If competitors consistently bid high, will test with low bids; if low, will increase my bids. Strategy aims to gather data and maximize long-term profits.

Next, I plan to bid slightly above half of my value to test opponents' reactions. If my value is high, I'll do an aggressive bid to observe their strategy. This will aid my future bidding decisions and potentially maximize the user profit.

My plan is to bid at 50% of my value for the initial rounds to gather data while contingently lessening losses. Analysing collected data, I will strategically select either aggressive, moderate, or conservative bids and adjust based on observed patterns.

Next, I'll implement incremental bidding, starting at the lower end around $30. I'll increase or decrease by $5 each round observing opponents' reactions. I aim to note their strategy during a series of rising or falling bids, helping me estimate a profitable midpoint in future rounds.

Looking at the previous bids, I plan to bid aggressively again this round, regardless of my value. Winning the bidding might provide more insight and help formulate a more effective, profit-maximizing strategy for future rounds.

Considering previous rounds, I plan to choose an aggressive strategy by bidding close to my value. However, I won't overbid to avoid incurring losses. Understanding patterns of competitors' bids will help balance aggressiveness with calculated risk. I'll continue adjusting my strategy based on auction outcomes.

Next, I'll focus on aggressive bidding strategy to gauge reactions. Bids will start high, around $80, and then be decreased by $5-$10 in subsequent rounds, observing rival responses for improved long-term decision making.

To maximize long-term profit, my plan for upcoming rounds includes variable bids - placing high risks bets when my value is high, bidding slightly above the average during intermediary values, and low risk-taking when my value is low. This mixed strategy should give valuable insights for refining future bids.

Given the past auctions, I aim to adopt a mixed strategy. It involves near-to-value bids for high-value items, mid-range bids for average value items, and conservative bids for low-value prizes. This flexible approach adjusts based on competitor patterns, helping maximize overall profit.

Next, I will explore the tactic of bidding slightly above the second highest bids of previous rounds. I'll also factor in the unpredictability of value drawings when placing aggressive or conservative bids, refining adaptive strategy based on collected data.

Next, I plan to bid aggressively on high values and conservatively on low values. I will also strategically place mid-ranged bids to observe reactions. This balance of risk-taking and careful bidding aims to maximize long-term profit.

I aim to test a strategy of bidding up to 75% of my value for high-value items, around 50% for mid-range values, and conservatively for low-value items to increase potential profits without risking significant losses.

I will implement a fluid bidding strategy, adjusting by $5-$10 according to rivals' bids. This includes conservatively placing bids slightly above or beneath their range, and aggressively, if low value rounds return frequently.

For the next round, I plan to make a mid-range bid if my value is low, and upscale my bid as my value increases. I'll also incorporate occasional high bids to gauge competitors' responses, allowing for a more informed, long-term profitable strategy.

Planning to test lower yet competitive bids to optimize profit margins. May bid down to 70-80% for high values, 50-60% for mid-range, and conservatively for low values, adjusting based on observed competition patterns, while prioritizing overall profit maximization.

Next, I will deliberately underbid to probe opponents' reactions to low bids. Also, I will alternate bids between mid, high, and low ranges. Such randomized bidding may instill unpredictability, confusing them, and allowing me to observe their patterns more thoroughly.

I plan to engage in variable aggressive bidding, placing high risk bets on high values, and testing opponents' reactions with mid-range bids on low values. This would maximize long-term profit by making informed bids based on opponents' responses, while balancing risk-taking and rewards.

My plan involves implementing a variable bidding strategy. For high values, I'll bid 70%-80%, for mid-values around 50%-60%, and conservatively for low values. The strategy could also incorporate the past bidding behaviour of the competitors and adapt accordingly to improve profits.

Plan: Strategically raise bids to outdo second highest, implement patterned fluctuation ($5-$10) for confusion, and observe rival reactions on low value rounds for competitive advantage. Improve adaptation and resilience throughout this unpredictability testing.

For upcoming rounds, I'll bid high on superior values and conservatively on inferior ones. Adding occasional random high-risk bids across all value ranges will help gauge opponents' reactions, aiding in devising a more informed, long-term profitable strategy.

I'll experiment with slightly lower bids, around 60-70% of my value for high values, 40-50% for mid-values, and conservatively for low values. This riskier approach could potentially maximize profit by reducing payment if won, yet might increase the chances of losing auctions.

Next, I will oscillate bids between low-middle-high ranges to observe opponent strategies. Considering potential recurring low values, I will experiment with a moderately aggressive approach, and occasionally bid slightly above value if it's towards the lower end of the spectrum.

I'll experiment with two bidding strategies: winning bids with a margin of $1 over second-highest previous winning bids and bidding high for high values while placing low cautious bids for low values, observing competitors' responses to both strategies for profit maximization.

For the next rounds, I'll aim to bid 65-70% of high values, 40-45% for mid-values, and bid conservatively for low-value items. This strategy balances risk-seeking exploration with maintaining moderate to high potential profits, factoring past competitor behaviors.

Next, plan to utilize a dynamic strategy, fluctuating bids across the value spectrum. This includes aggressive bids when value is low, conservative bids slightly below my value when high, and continuing to observe rival behaviors for data-driven decisions and long-term profit maximization.

To ensure maximum profit, I'll explore aggressive high-value bidding while maintaining caution with lower values. I'll periodically place bids slightly above the average of my opponents' bids to gather strategic data on their potential reactions and incorporate this for future bidding decisions.

Plan to maintain a dynamic strategy: bidding 60-65% for high values, 35-40% for mid-range, and conservatively for lower values. Constantly evaluate competitor trends and performance of my strategy. Further adjustment to optimize winning difference will be made based on data analysis from upcoming rounds.

Next, I plan to adjust my bids dynamically, basing them on the spread between highest and second highest bids in the past rounds. Periodically, I will also underbid regardless of high values drawn, to gauge competitors' reactions and adapt more effectively.

Next, I plan to bid closer to the second-highest previous bid on high values, while placing cautious bids on low values. Additionally, I'll place random high-risk bids to analyze opponents' reactions, assisting in formulating an effective, long-term profit-maximizing strategy.

I'll implement a dynamic strategy, bidding 60% for high values, 35% for mid-range, and minimum for low-value items. Evaluating competitor trends and performance of my strategy constantly, further adjustments will be made based on data analysis from upcoming rounds to optimize potential profits.

Plan to adapt strategy based on their average bids. Initiate small adjustments, +$2 or -$2, to observe reactions. Explore under-bidding with high values and over-bidding with lower ones; occasionally place unpredictable bids, while maintaining long-term profit aim. Integrate these lessons to formulate adaptive bidding approach.

I'll test a mixed strategy: high-risk bidding for high values, strategic average bids for middling values, low-risk bidding for low values. Periodic surprise high bids across all ranges will provide valuable competitive insights to refine my long-term profit-maximization strategy.

Plan to implement a flexible approach: bidding 55-60% for high values, 30-35% for mid-values, and lower for low-value items. Continual assessments of competitors' trends and expected yields. Introduce variable bid adjustments depending on context and to mitigate risk, aiming for long term profit maximization.

Next, I'll consider the average of my opponents' bids and add or subtract $1-$2. I'll also experiment with underbidding when my value is high and occasionally overbid when my value is low to learn from their responses.

Moving forward, I plan to bid slightly above the second-highest bid of previous rounds when values are high. I'll employ a cautious approach for lower values and sporadically undertake high-risk bids to test opponents' reactions for devising an effective long-term profit-maximizing strategy.

Will continue with dynamic bidding: 55-60% for high value, 30-35% for mid-range, low for low-value items. Adapt bid percentages based on the competition pattern and my value to maintain a balance between profitability and winning likelihood. Analyze previous outcomes to strategically adjust bids within the planned range.

Next, I'll strategize bidding around the average of previous top bids. Meanwhile, continue exploring benefits of periodic aggressive overbidding, slightly above value and observe their responses. I'll also investigate underbidding when my drawn value is surprisingly high, to puzzle opponents and gain insights.

I plan to bid cautiously on low values, near previous second-highest bids for high values. I'll place occasional high-risk bids to evaluate opponents' reactions. This mixed-strategy aims to balance risk and reward, targeting long-term profit maximization based on learned strategies.

Maintain dynamic bidding. For high values, bid 55-60% of value, for mid-range 30-35%, for low values, bid conservatively. Adjust within these ranges based on bidder trends. Prioritize long-term profit growth. Increase deviation in bid values to analyze effect on profits.

Plan: Continue dynamic bidding; high when value is low, low when high. Consider average of opponents' top bids, add/subtract $1-$2 for unpredictability. Deliberately underbid with high values occasionally to assess reactions. Navigate towards maximizing long-term profit with lessons from previous rounds.

I'll adopt a dynamic approach: high-risk bids for high values, cautious bids for low values. I'll place occasional surprise bids slightly above the previous rounds' average bid across all value ranges to glean insights into opponents' strategies, to tailor an optimal long-term strategy.

I'll adjust my bid strategy to 60-65% for high values, 35-40% for mid-range values and conservatively for low values. I'll increase variance in my bids to test outcomes and continue adjusting based on competitor behavior and bid results to maximize long-term profits.
